nodes.text: Yes
No

Being asked to pay a small sum of money to an official as a fine can sometimes be a facilitation payment in disguise. However, as this is a published fine and you will get a receipt it is unlikely to be a facilitation payment in this instance.  Be cautious though and if you are in any doubt do not pay.

We make no distinction between facilitation payments and bribes, no matter how small the amount. Facilitation payments are illegal in most countries in which we operate and UK law forbids them anywhere in the world.
Obtain a receipt detailing the reason for and the amount of the charge.
Record the transaction appropriately.
If you are in any doubt do not pay.
If you feel that your safety or liberty is threatened and you are being coerced into paying, then you should pay.
You must record the payment and the circumstances and report them as soon as possible to your line manager and the legal or compliance department.
Record the payment clearly and when claiming the cost back from the company, make sure it is clearly identified and accounted for

Gifts are a legitimate part of business life and are often exchanged.  However it is possible that accepting a gift can put people into situations which lay them open to accusations of bribery. The more lavish a gift the more likely it is to be regarded with suspicion and its purpose questioned.

We have deliberately limited the type of gift that you can accept in order to protect you from getting into a position where your integrity, impartiality or judgement might be challenged or the company's reputation might be damaged if you accept certain gifts.

The acceptance of this gift would be in breach of the policy and you must not accept it.  Any gifts we do receive in connection with our business should always be customary and reasonable in terms of value and frequency.  As this gift is not within the policy we do not consider it to be reasonable.

Whilst you may believe that the gift is offered with no ulterior motive it could be misinterpreted by others who could perceive the acceptance of the gift as making you or your decisions biased, conflicted or obligated. There can sometimes be a fine line between a gift and a bribe. It is safer to decline than take the risk.

Do not be embarrassed to decline the gift and be clear that you are by doing so in writing.  Simply explain that you are not in a position to accept it using the rules and the reasons given here as explanation.
Report this gift offer to your line manager, the bid contract or the Legal department and be clear that you have declined it.
If you have a gift and hospitality register make sure you record the gift and the fact you declined it on this too.
A gift of electronic equipment is considered to be of significant value and non standard and is therefore likely to raise questions about the purpose for offering it.
Be particularly cautious as being offered electronic equipment is probably only intended to be used by you for your own personal benefit and it could not be shared easily.

Accepting a gift like this could put you under undue obligation or affect your judgement.  Consider what contact you are likely to have with this person in the future and how your relationship might work if you accept the equipment.

Talk to your line manager or HR as a gift of this nature would be considered to be substantial value.   Any gifts we receive in connection with our business should always be customary and reasonable in terms of value.  This is clearly not the case.
